field_edited_text.value:
Chesapeake Bay Bridge





BAY FERRIES

AT PRESENT the Chesapeake Bay is crossed by three ferry services.
One ferry operates between Baltimore and Tolchester and provides pri-
marily an excursion trip to transport patrons from Baltimore to a pleasure
beach at Tolchester. The service includes scheduled trips from Baltimore
to Tolchester, but has been intermittent for the last few years, with long
periods during which the sailings were discontinued.

A ferry is operated from Baltimore to Love Point which transports
automobiles, freight and passengers. It connects, at Love Point, with a
branch of the Pennsylvania Railroad. The railroad service has been re-
duced to very limited service, but the ferry service is still maintained.

The principal ferry service is operated from Annapolis to Matapeake and
transports automobiles, passengers and motor trucks between Annapolis
and the Eastern Shore. Formerly a direct connection was maintained be-
tween Annapolis and Claiborne, but this service has recently been changed.
A shuttle ferry operating from the southern end of Kent Island to Claiborne
now replaces the former direct service from Annapolis to Claiborne.

The State Roads Commission has had negotiations with the company
operating this ferry looking toward an arbitration agreement, to determine
the price to be paid by the Commission for the ferry, if the Commission
determines to construct a Chesapeake Bay Bridge.

BRIDGE SITES

As stated in the preamble of Chapter 356 of the Laws of Maryland
of 1937, the Chesapeake Bay stretches 130 miles from the southern boundary
line of Maryland to the upper regions of the Bay without any bridge or
tunnel crossing. This handicap to quick transportation by automobile
would be removed by the construction of a bridge, and such lack of a bridge
not only interferes with the quick transportation of passengers and goods,
but results in a handicap to the agricultural and industrial development of

127
